meanings.def: to rub your skin with your nails, usually because it is itching
examples: scratch something John yawned and scratched his chin.
scratch (yourself) The dog scratched itself behind the ear.
Try not to scratch.
scratch at something She scratched at the insect bites on her arm.
He absently scratched his head.
He kept scratching at his nose.
He scratched at his beard for a few seconds.

meanings.def: to cut or damage your skin slightly with something sharp
examples: scratch (somebody/something/yourself) I'd scratched my leg and it was bleeding.
Does the cat scratch?
scratch somebody/something/yourself on something She scratched herself on a nail.
I scratched my arm on a rose bush.
She scratched his face with her nails.
She had obviously tried to scratch her attacker.

meanings.def: to damage the surface of something, especially by accident, by making thin shallow marks on it
examples: Be careful not to scratch the furniture.
The car's paintwork is badly scratched.

meanings.def: to make or remove a mark, etc. on something deliberately, by rubbing it with something hard or sharp
examples: They scratched lines in the dirt to mark out a pitch.
Some graffiti had been scratched on the back of the door.
We scratched some of the dirt away.
(figurative) You can scratch my name off the list.

meanings.def: to make an annoying noise by rubbing something with something sharp
examples: His pen scratched away on the paper.
We could hear mice scratching behind the wall.
The dog kept scratching at the door to go out.

meanings.def: to make enough money to live on, but with difficulty
examples: 75% of the population scratch a living from the soil.

meanings.def: to decide that something cannot happen or somebody/something cannot take part in something, before it starts
examples: scratch somebody/something to scratch a rocket launch
scratch somebody/something from something The horse was scratched from the race because of injury.
scratch (from something) She had scratched because of a knee injury.

meanings.def: to think hard in order to find an answer to something
examples: Experts have been scratching their heads over the increase in teenage crime.

meanings.def: to deal with, understand, or find out about only a small part of a subject or problem
examples: We left feeling that we had just scratched the surface of this fascinating country.
The investigation barely scratched the surface of the city's drug problem.

meanings.def: used to say that if somebody helps you, you will help them, even if this is unfair to others

meanings.def: a mark, a cut or an injury made by scratching somebody’s skin or the surface of something
examples: Her hands were covered in scratches from the brambles.
a scratch on the paintwork
It's only a scratch (= a very slight injury).
without a scratch He escaped without a scratch (= was not hurt at all).
I've got some nasty scratches on my legs.
Powdered cleansers will leave scratches on the glass.

meanings.def: the unpleasant sound of something sharp or rough being rubbed against a surface
the act of scratching a part of your body when it itches
examples: Go on, have a good scratch!

meanings.def: without any previous preparation or knowledge
examples: I learned German from scratch in six months.
He built the orchestra up from scratch.

meanings.def: from the very beginning, not using any of the work done earlier
examples: They decided to dismantle the machine and start again from scratch.

meanings.def: as good as something/somebody should be
examples: His work simply isn't up to scratch.
It'll take months to bring the band up to scratch.

a scratch player
